718788f-a.title: Manhattan: Christopher Street - 7th Avenue
718788f-a.text:
Christopher Street, north side, east of, a point east of Seventh Avenue, as viewed from Grove Street (east side of this
open area).
In the center is Waverly Place, and the Northern Dispensary. The spired structure in the background is Jefferson Mahket Court.
1895
J. J. Corell
P. L. Sperr

723185f-a.title: Manhattan: 4th Street (West) - Washington Place
723185f-a.text:
Store, formerly an old tavern, at 1-2 Sheridan Square, east side, seen from the West 4th Street side, looking towards 127-125, 123, 12l Washington Place, the aix-story apartment house and the two 1ittle houses which can be seen on the north side of Washington
Place east of Sheridan Square.
Later in the decade No. 1-2 Sheridan Square will be remodelled, and
another story will be added.
1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

718785f-a.title: Manhattan: Christopher Street - 4th Street (West)
718785f-a.text:
85 to 75 Christopher Street, north side, west of and towards upper West 4th Street and Seventh Avenue South. No. 81 is St. Tohn's Evangelical Lutheran (German) Church, which was established here around the time of the Civil War; but the church edifice itself was probably inherited from St. Mathew's Protestant Episcopal Church,
which stood on the same site.
October V4, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.

the Avenue.

710921f-a.title: Manhattan: 4th Street - Christopher Street
710921f-a.text:
4th Street (to the left) north from Christopher Street, at Seventh Avenue South. This part of 4th Street is an old Village street, shown on an 1803 map as Chester Street and on the 1811 city survey (when the numbered streets and avenues were first planned) as William Street. Before long, however, the true 4th Street on the East Side was extended to this point, and that number was applied to this street all the way to its terminus at 13th and
Gansevoort Streets, west of Eighth Avenue.
The block on the east side of 4th Street, from Christopher to 10th (formerly Amos) Streets, was broken up when Seventh Avenue South was cut through around 1914. All that was left west of Seventh Avenue South were Nos. 229-31 West 4th Street, shown in this picture with the Sinclair Motor 0il advertisement on the side of 229. The building shown in part on the left is the new one built in 1931 on the site of the Greenwich Village Theatre, which itself was built on the old N.W. corner of 4th and Christopher Streets after Seventh
Avenue South was cut through.
233 West 4th Street, on the N.E. corner of 10th Street, is a fairly
new apartment house.
March 25, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

710922f-a.title: Manhattan: 4th Street - Washington Place
710922f-a.text:
4th Street (right), and Washington Place (left), east from Grove Street, showing also Sheridan Square in the foreground. Sheridan Square is a triangle with its apex pointing west and located at the vestern end of Washington Place (originally West 5th Street); the northern side is the northern side of Washington Place, and the southern side follows the line of West 4th Street (formerly Asylum Street). Sheridan Square house numbers begin on the short eastern side, which was originally the eastern end of Reason Street (now the eastern section of Barrow Street, G.v.), and follow in
order clockwise around Sheridan Square.
June 24, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
Nicg ~ 0S
